qas.question: In what area of Kathmandu is the National Museum?
What stupa is close to the National Museum?
Who built the building that contains the National Museum?
When was the National Museum founded?

answers.text: the stone house of arms and ammunition

context: The National Museum is located in the <a0_0>western<a0_0/> part of Kathmandu, near the <a1_0>Swayambhunath<a1_0/> stupa in an historical building. This building was constructed in the early 19th century by General <a2_0>Bhimsen Thapa<a2_0/>. It is the most important museum in the country, housing an extensive collection of weapons, art and antiquities of historic and cultural importance. The museum was established in <a3_0>1928<a3_0/> as a collection house of war trophies and weapons, and the initial name of this museum was Chhauni Silkhana, meaning "<a4_0>the stone house of arms and ammunition<a4_0/>". Given its focus, the museum contains many weapons, including locally made firearms used in wars, leather cannons from the 18th–19th century, and medieval and modern works in wood, bronze, stone and paintings.
